loans.name: Qurbongul

texts.ru:
Курбонгул жительница района Хуросон. Ей 67 лет, она вдова. Курбонгул живет вместе с сыном, невесткой и двумя внуками. Она как и многие ее односельчане занимается животноводством. 6 лет назад она начала свой бизнес по купле и продаже крупнорогатых скотов, который продолжает по сей день. Ей в деятельности помогает невестка.
Курбонгул и ее семья живет в отдаленном кишлаке, почти на окраине района. В их село транспортное средство совсем не ходит, поэтому им очень трудно добираться от их села до района и от района до их села. Курбонгул давно хочет купить машину, но из-за нехватки финансов не может осуществить свою цель. Она решила взять в кредит недостающую сумму и купить наконец автомобиль. Курбонгул очень надеется на финансовую поддержку, так как хочет улучшить жизненные обстоятельства.
texts.en: Qurbongul is a resident of the Khuroson district. She is 67 years old and a widow. Qurbongul lives with her son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren. Just like many of her village neighbors, she is involved in animal husbandry. She started her own business in reselling cattle 6 years ago and continues it to this day. Her daughter-in-law helps her with the business. Qurbongul and her family live in a remote village, almost at the edge of the district. Public transportation is almost unavailable in their village, making it very difficult for them to get from the village to the district and vice versa. Qurbongul has been wanting to purchase a car for a long time, but has not been able to achieve her goal due to the lack of finances. She decided to obtain a loan for the remaining amount and finally buy a car. Qurbongul really hopes for the financial support because she wants to improve her life circumstances.

loans.use: to purchase a car

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa is a married man and a father of four children, all of whom attend school. He lives at his own house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past ten years, he has operated a business selling clothes from door to door to his neighbours and passersby. The high cost of transportation is a major challenge that he faces. He dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

Musa decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business. With the loan of KES 20,000 that he is requesting, he wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Babban Liya Ibrahim

texts.en:
Babban Liya Ibrahim is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, he would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Babban Liya Ibrahim can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Babban Liya Ibrahim is looking to earn a better income, to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Eseza

texts.en:
Eseza is married with 4 children, all of whom go to school. Her family's house has access to neither electricity nor piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.  

Eseza has a business selling charcoal. She works from her home seven days a week and says her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has applied for a loan of 500,000 UGX from Micro Credit Development and Transformation SACCO in order to buy more bags of charcoal. 

Eseza aspires to pay for her children's education through to the university level.

loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.ru: Махмуд, 56 лет, женат, 2 детей. Около 18 лет назад открыл свое кафе. На сегодняшний день Махмуд смог развить свою деятельность, постепенно приобретает хорошую мебель для кафе. В бизнесе помогает супруга, дочь, дополнительно работает 6 человек (официанты, помощник повара и т.д.). Ежемесячная прибыль составляет примерно 18,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса Махмуд обратился в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 150,000 сом (KGS) на покупку мебели, часть средств направит на приобретение лука и картошки на зиму. Доходы от кредита Махмуд планирует направить на расширение клиентуры кафе и дальнейшее его развитие.
texts.en: Mahmud is 56 years old, married and has 2 children. He opened his own cafe about 18 years ago. To-date, Mahmud has been able to develop his business and gradually buy good furniture for the cafe. His wife and daughter help him with the business, and additionally 6 more people (waiters, assistant cook, etc.) work there. The monthly profit amounts to about 18,000 som (KGS). In order to further develop his business, Mahmud requested a loan in the amount of 150,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy furniture and also onions and potatoes for the winter. Mahmud plans to direct the earnings from loan toward expanding his customer base and further developing his cafe.

loans.use: to buy furniture and also onions and potatoes for the winter

loans.name: Abida

texts.en:
Abida is a 43-year-old married woman. She deals in business selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices, raises them, and then sells them in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. She also sells milk to generate extra income.

Abida needs to improve her business to meet her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 45,000 to purchase more animals to increase her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income level.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to increase her sales.

loans.name: Nazia

texts.en: Nazia is 35 years old, married and the mother of four children. Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled vehicle. He has earned a living as a driver for many years as a way to meet family expenses, but his vehicle now requires maintenance to stay in proper condition. For this reason, Nazia is requesting a Murabaha loan for 35,000 PKR for her husband, so that he can provide better service by buying new tires and a new auto body for his rickshaw.

loans.use: to buy new tires and a new auto body for her husband's rickshaw.

loans.name: Terry

texts.en:
Terry is 56 years old. She is married to Benard, and together they have been blessed with three children of 19, 16 and 13 years.  Terry is a farmer, a business she has done for the last seven years, earning a monthly income of KES 7,000.

Terry has requested for her 4th loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 30,000, which she will use to buy seedlings for planting and fertilizers. With the anticipated profits, Terry will be able to expand her business, as well as get enough for school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy seedlings for planting and fertilizers.

loans.name: Badriyah

texts.en:
Badriyah is a 54-year-old Palestinian, widowed mother of six children who has worked in her grocery shop since 1998 to cover the needs and expenses of her family.

Badriyah is the sole earner of her family. She is trying hard to improve their living conditions and develop her business, thus today she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, to increase her business merchandise with new requested products to satisfy her customers' needs during the winter, especially in the Christmas season.

Badriyah hopes to further expand her business in the future, to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with new requested products to satisfy her customers' needs during the winter.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
For years, rural women have lived poor lives thanks to disinheritance, patriarchal systems and lack of mentors. In addition, in some parts of Kenya like Litein, more women were rendered poor by the clashes that followed the disputed presidential elections of 2007. Their men were killed and property destroyed, leaving women that were once financially stable and even of middle-income bracket, vulnerable to poverty. Years down the line, Juhudi Kilimo, a microfinance institution that concentrates on small holder farmers, came to their rescue, training marginalized women from rural areas on how to do agriculture better, and advertise and sell their farm produce directly to the market. 

Monica from “Excel Self Help Group” in Eldoret applauds the initiative for transforming her life. She is a loving mum to three angel-looking children and has been farming for the past 10 years. Monica passionately loves dairy farming, and this can be attested to by the fact that she knows her cows, each individually, because she works with them twice a day, 365 days a year. She and her husband have even named one of them “Brown.” 

Monica practices mixed farming and through this humble task she aspires to offer all of her children a university education. Monica learned to do farm work at a young age, thanks to her parents. She has a tiny plot of land to live off – just under half an acre – and has always struggled to support her family. She has developed the farm in the sloping, undulating terrain by successfully adopting suitable soil and water conservation methods, such as stone pitched bench terracing and digging rainwater storage pits. Milking and feeding her own cows is the most enjoyable part about farming. She is very appreciative that dairy farming has been able to sustain farmers in her village. 

Profits from milk sales have enabled her to take care of her family, and she wants her cows to produce more milk. That is why she is seeking a loan to buy animal feed. With this animal feed, her cows will be able to increase milk production, which will translate to increased income. She believes that through careful selection and the application of the strict standard of excellence in keeping her dairy cows, she will have more income, which will improve her living standards.

loans.use: to buy animal feed.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en:
Haruna is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Haruna joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Abdul, Asiya, and Nana.  

In the past, because he needed to pay urgent expenses, Haruna would typically have sold his maize soon after harvest, but when the price was lowest.

However, now that he is a member, with this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Haruna can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more.

When asked, Haruna spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are well-educated and obtain professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for child school fees and uniforms, eliminating pressure to sell his harvest at low prices.

loans.name: Doris Araceli

texts.es: Doña Doris, tiene 51 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene 4 hijos y reside en el municipio de Azacualpa con la compañía de una hija menor. Doña Doris lleva 10 años de tener su propio negocio para generar ingresos para la familia.  Tiene una pulpería donde vende productos de la canasta básica familiar como ser azúcar, harina de maíz, condimentos, frijoles, manteca, huevos, jabón, productos enlatados, pastas, pastillas, refrescos, churros y otros abarrotes. Este negocio lo inicio con fondos propios y lo ha ido aumentando con las ganancias. Actualmente ha decidido solicitar un préstamo por 15,000 Lempiras para invertirlo en la compra de mas productos para vender como ser azúcar, arroz, frijoles, maíz, sal, café, pan, huevos, leche, condimentos, harina, manteca y productos de aseo. Con esta inversion piensa seguir manteniendo su negocio para aumentar el inventario y sus ingresos. Su meta propuesta es que el negocio crezca para que sea su fuente de ingresos familiares y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en: Doris is 51 years old, she is a single mother, has 4 children and lives in the municipality of Azacualpa with her youngest daughter.  Doris has 10 years with her own business to generate income for her family.  She has a convenience store where she sells basic products such as sugar, corn flour, condiments, beans, lard, eggs, soap, canned products, pasta, pain killers, sodas, churros and other groceries.  This business was started with her own resources and she has been improving it with the profits.  Currently she is requesting a loan for 15,000 HNL to buy more products for sale such as sugar, rice, beans, corn, salt, coffee, bread, eggs, milk, condiments, flour, lard and cleaning products.  With this investment she plans to keep her business in good shape to increase inventory and income.  Her goal is to grow the business so that it's her source of family income and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more products for sale such as sugar, rice, beans, corn, salt, coffee, bread, eggs, milk, condiments, flour, lard and cleaning products.

loans.name: Jameela

texts.en:
Jameela is a 53-year-old married woman. She is a very talented lady and excels in her work of stitching. She has gotten a lot of appreciation from her community. Some years ago she started her business of tailoring to help run her household activities. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

She has now requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase more spools of threads, ribbons, cloth, needles and scissors for stitching up more dresses on time to get a boost in her earnings. She wishes to spend her increased income on providing a quality life for her family members.

loans.use: to purchase more spools of threads, ribbons, cloth, needles and scissors for stitching up more dresses on time to get a boost in her earnings

loans.name: Sylivier

texts.en:
Sylivier is 43 years old. He is married with five children aged between 1 and 14 years, 4 of whom go to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for 20 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers to grow maize, which he will then sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers to grow maize, which he will then sell

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en: Jalal is a thirty-nine-year-old married father of three children. He is acquiring this loan to pay his children's school tuition fees. The loan is part of Al Majmoua's Back to School program, designed to finance school expenses such as books, stationery, transportation and fees for students with low family incomes. Funds can be used for partial or complete payment of school expenses. By supporting this loan, you are enabling access to education for students with limited options. Jalal hopes to stay capable of providing his children with the necessary living needs, and developing their social situation.

loans.use: to pay his children's school tuition fees

loans.name: Amor Y Efuerzo Group

texts.es: Ledy, tiene 37 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene a su cargo 3 hijos, reside con ellos en el Municipio de Yoro. Ledy lleva cinco años de haber decidido por tener su propio negocio, vende granos básicos como maíz y frijoles. Este negocio lo tiene en su casa y es su fuente de ingresos para el sostenimiento familiar. Ha solicitado el tercer ciclo de préstamo a la institución que es por 9,000 lempiras y en forma grupal, este préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de maíz y frijoles para revender y obtener ingresos. Su plan es seguir trabajando con la inversión y hacer crecer el negocio para mejorar su nivel de vida darles educación a sus hijos. El grupo se llama Amor y Efuerzo, integrado por cuatro mujeres,viven en la misma comunidad, ellas se dedican a comercializar granos básicos. Solicitan un préstamo por 35,000 Lempiras para comprar granos básicos y vender. En la foto esta Ledy a la izquierda, María Quirotilde, María Emérita y Ludis a la derecha.
texts.en:
Ledy is a 37 year old single mom of three children. She lives with them in the Municipality of Yoro. It has been five years since Ledy decided to open her own business selling basic grains such as corn and beans. 


She runs this business from her home and it is her source of income to support her family. She asks the institution for the third cycle of the loan for 9,000 Honduran Lempiras to buy corn and beans to resell and generate revenue for the group. 


Her plan is to utilize the loan to continue working and to grow the business to improve their quality of life and give their children access to education. The group is called Amor and Esfuerzo (Love and Effort) and is made up of four women who live in the same community. They make a living selling basic grains. 


They ask for a loan for 35,000 Honduran Lempiras to buy basic grains to sell. Depicted from left to right in the photo: Ledy, María Quirotilde, María Emérita and Ludis.

loans.use: to buy

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es:
Juan, de 48 años de edad,  estudió hasta cuarto grado de educación básica, está casado desde hace 20 años y su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos, tienen 3 hijos, de los cuales dos estudian y el otro colabora con los trabajos agrícolas que Juan realiza.

Juan, es agricultor y se ha dedica a esta actividad desde hace 30 años, el trabajo lo aprendió de su padre quien desde pequeño le enseño.- Además, de trabajar en la agricultura, también es fontanero en una asociación de agua dentro de su misma comunidad, generando así un ingreso adicional para el sostenimiento de su familia.

Su trabajo está cerca de su casa por lo que no se le dificulta llegar y su horario de trabajo es de 6 horas al día.

El préstamo de Juan es para comprar una novilla, porque quiere aprovechar los residuos de la cosecha de maíz que sacará en los próximos días y esto le sirve de alimento al ganado. 
Además, el aprovechará los lácteos que produzca la novilla para la sana alimentación de su familia.

Los sueños que Juan tiene son: tener su propio puesto para vender sus productos agrícolas en el lugar donde vive; para sus hijos desea que sigan estudiando para culminen una carrera universitaria.
texts.en:
Juan is 48, he studied up to 4th grade of basic education, he has been married for 20 years and his wife works providing domestic services, they have 3 children of which two are students and the other one helps Juan with agriculture chores.

Juan works in agriculture, he has worked on this activity for 30 years, he learned to work from his father who taught him when he was little.  Also, in addition to agriculture he is a plumber at a water association in his community.  This way he is generating a extra income to earn a living for his family.

His work is located close from his house, so it's not difficult to get there and his work shift is 6 hours per day.

Juan's loan is to buy a calf, he wants to take advantage of the residual from corn harvest that he will have in the next few days and this will be used as feed for the calf.  Also he will use the dairy from the calf to feed his family. 

Juan's dreams are to have his own store to sell agricultural products in the area where he lives, have his children continue studying to complete a university degree.

loans.use: to buy a calf.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a 57-year-old married woman doing business in animal purchase and sales with the help of her husband for many years. Her business has provided her family with a decent life. She is the mother of 5 children. She is very motivated to provide them with a beautiful life including good education, food and clothing.

She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR. She intends to utilize this loan amount to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers. She is hopeful that her business will generate greater revenue in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers and generate greater revenue in the future.

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en:
Sumaira is a 32-year-old married woman. She has one child. She is a vigorous lady and, for the past many years, has been running a cloth purchase and sales business. She buys cloth in various fabrics, in different colors and designs, from the market at wholesale rates and then sells them to the people of her community. She has a varied customer base and is able to earn enough through her business.

Now, she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her business. She hopes to have a good experience with this new loan. Sumaira expects a boost in her earnings with the loan and she plans to spend part of her profits for the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with one child who attends school and is under her care. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

For over three years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door and from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan 30,000 KES that she is requesting, she wants to purchase a bale of kids clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of kids clothes for resale

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
Arminda es una mujer de 47 años de edad, casada, tiene 3 hijos varones y una hija mujer, y su negocio es la venta de comida tradicional.
Ella es buena madre, paciente, buena oyente, solidaria, fuerte, emprendedora, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘Lacma’ que se caracteriza por su gran densidad poblacional y cuyas principales actividades económicas son las de comercio y manufactura. Se encuentra ubicado a una altura aproximada de 2500 metros sobre el nivel del mar y tiene una temperatura templada todo el año.
Armina es de tez morena, cabello negro largo, baja estatura, su lengua materna es el Quechua y habla español por cultura general y por el comercio que realiza (la primera de la derecha, usa suéter azul, blusa naranja). Su vida la comparte con su esposo que se dedica al transporte y sus hijos que trabajan y estudian. Viven en una casa propia construida de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad y alcantarillado. Sus deseos de ampliar su negocio la llevaron a formar una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de chompas, venta de materiales de construcción, tejido de ropa de bebe, venta de papas fritas, venta de ropa deportiva, tienda de barrio, carnicería y  venta de sándwiches, para solicitar un préstamo y prosperar con sus negocios. Su negocio es la venta de comida tradicional, y esta se caracteriza por tener un menú diario de lunes a domingo, como; Lunes: Ají de flores de chilijchi (Flores de ceibo rehogadas con cebolla, tomate y locoto, y papas blancas), Martes: Conejo lambreado (Cuy rebozado con pan molido y frito, rociado con chorrillana y con guarniciones de chuño p’uti y papa blanca), Miércoles: Chajchu (Filamentos de carne de res, cebolla verde, habas tiernas, chuño picado, tajadas de huevo duro, salsa de cebolla a la juliana, tomate y locoto, y ahogado de ají colorado), Jueves: Chanka de conejo (Cuy tierno cocido y aromado con hierbabuena, cebolla verde, haba tierna, papa blanca y llajua de locoto. También se prepara de gallina), Viernes: Chicharrón de cerdo (Cocido al perol en su propia manteca, con mote de maíz blanco y llajua de locoto), Sábado: Fidius uchú (Ají de tallarines con caldo espeso, colitas de vaca, chuño y papa), Domingo: Phampaku (Versión valluna de la huatía con carnes de pato, lechón, cordero, pollo y lappin condimentadas. Se sirve con papa y plátanos al horno y ensaladas). “mi lema; El arte de preparar una buena comida…” comenta. Su sueño es ampliar su negocio. Ella desea realizar una inversión mediante la compra de mesas, sillas y utensilios de cocina para atender a mayor cantidad de clientes. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 13 años que viene realizando esta actividad. 
Es por esos motivos que Arminda solicita un préstamo para la ampliación de su negocio mediante la compra de mesas, sillas y utensilios de cocina.
texts.en:
Arminda is a 47 year old lady. She is married, has three sons and a daughter, and works selling traditional food. She is a good mother, and is patient, a good listener, caring, strong, enterprising, responsible and hard working. She works in the 'Lacma' zone, which is characterized by a highly population density and of which the main economic activities are commerce and manufacturing. It is located at approximately 2500 meters above sea level and has a temperate climate throughout the year.

Arminda has a dark complexion, long black hair, and is of short stature. Her maternal language is Quechua and she also speaks Spanish due to the general culture, and for her work. (She is the first on the right, with a blue sweater and an orange blouse). She lives with her spouse, who works in transport, and her children who work and study. They live in a house that they own themselves, fitted with running water, electricity and a sewage system. Her wishes to expand her business lead her to form a group of people with business such as: selling sweaters, selling construction material, knitting baby clothes, selling potato chips, selling sports clothing, local store, butcher, and selling sandwiches, in order to request a loan and allow their businesses to thrive.

Her business is the selling of traditional food, for which she has a daily menu each day from Monday to Sunday, for example:
Monday: Ají de flores de chilijchi (ceibo flowers sautéed with onion, tomato, pepper and white potatoes)
Tuesday: Conejo lambreado (guinea pig coated in breadcrumbs and fried, served with chorrillana and with potato and egg)
Wednesday: Chajchu (strips of beef, green onion, tender beans, chopped freeze-dried potato, sliced boiled eggs, sliced onion sauce, tomato and pepper, and covered with ají colorado sauce.
Thursday: Chanka de conejo (tender guinea pig, cooked and flavored with mint, green onion, tender beans, white potato and llajua hot pepper sauce. Chicken is also prepared.
Friday: Pork chicharrón (cooked in a pot in its own fat, with white corn mote and llajua hot pepper sauce)
Saturday: Fidius uchú (noodles with ají sauce and a thick broth, oxtail, and potato)
Sunday: Phampaku ('valluna' version of a meat dish, with seasoned duck, piglet, lamb, chicken and beef. Served with oven baked banana and potato and salads.

She says "my slogan: The art of preparing a good meal..." Her dream is to expand her business. She wishes to invest in her business by buying tables, chairs and cooking utensils so that she can serve a larger number of customers. This is the first loan cycle with the institution in the thirteen years she has been doing this work.

It is for these reasons that Arminda is asking for a loan, so that she can expand her business by buying tables, chairs and cooking utensils.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying tables, chairs and kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Sale

texts.en:
Sale is a maize farmer from Gwanki village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Sale would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sale can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Sale, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Ana Rosalia

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Florón de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Grupo de Crédito Renacer.
En este lugar vive la señora Ana, tiene 70 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen siete hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo es comerciante.
Doña Ana es una muy buena esposa que realiza el crédito para ayudarle a su  esposo, el cual tiene una tercena en un local en el centro de la ciudad local el cual es alquilado y en el que vende carne de chancho, él se desplaza a los campos a comprar los chanchos para luego faenarlos y vender su carne en su local, tiene más de 40 años dedicado a esta actividad con la cual les dio una buena crianza a sus hijos.
Este crédito es para comprar chanchos para la venta diaria. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta ya que con los créditos ella puede ayudar a su marido. Sus sueños son tener buena salud para ella y su familia.
texts.en:
The citadel of El Floron is in the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabi, known for many years as the city of the Reales Tamarindos. The members of the Renacer credit group meet in El Floron every fifteen days.
Ana lives in El Floron. She is 70, married, and has seven grown and independent children. Her husband is a merchant.
Ana is a very good wife who is taking out a loan to help her husband, who has a butcher's shop downtown. He rents the store and sells pork. He goes to the countryside to buy the hogs to fatten and later sells their meat in his store. He has been doing this for over 40 years. Through this business, he has been able to raise his children well.
This loan is for the purchase of hogs for daily sale. Ana has been part of the credit group from the beginning and she likes the loans because she can help her husband. Her dreams are for her and her family to have good health.

loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different kinds of food for resale.

loans.name: Nteziryayo

texts.en: Nteziryao is 24 years old and not married.  He has a shop and has been in a business for six years. With the loan, he would like to buy more balls, socks and handkerchiefs for sale. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption..

loans.use: To buy more balls, socks and handkerchiefs for sale.

loans.name: Shuaibu

texts.en:
Shuaibu is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Shuaibu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Shuaibu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Shuaibu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Amadu

texts.en:
Amadu is a maize farmer from Chino village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Amadu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Amadu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Amadu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Muferanji Group

texts.en:
Aida is 36 years old and has three children who she supports. Aida is married to farmer, and she sells different products such as shoes and pots. This business helps her to financially support her family, as she depends on this business for her daily survival and to provide her family’s basic needs. 

Upon obtaining the loan, she will use it to expand her business by buying more products in order to increase her profits. 

Aida plans to open a large shop and hopes to improve her family’s living standards. The loans have helped her to become self-reliant, and she is now able to pay her family’s bills without any difficulties.

loans.use: to buy shoes

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
This is Rachel. She is 36 years old, married and blessed with two children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from the training on enterprise development. She is a small-scale farmer who does indigenous vegetable farming and also does dairy farming.

She is borrowing from Kiva to boost her farming business by buying manure. She is hopeful that this will improve her vegetable farming. She looks forward to improved income, and to be in a position to provide basic needs and better education for the children. Rachel is grateful to Kiva and all the lenders for the support and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy manure that will improve crop yield to earn more income, thus helping to provide better education for her children.

loans.name: Rita

texts.es: Rita es soltera y no tiene hijos, ella vive en la comunidad de Avichaca en una modesta casa de adobe que es de su propiedad, al menos tiene luz y agua. Rita se dedica a la produccion de leche, ella cuenta con unas cuantas cabezas de ganado que son de su propiedad Rita quiere un prestamo para comprar una vaca lechera, los padres de Rita le ayudan pero la familia no tiene situacion acomodada, por eso esta clienta quiere su ayuda, por cierto, ella goza de buena salud
texts.en:
Rita is single and does not have children. She lives in the Avichaca community in a modest adobe house which she owns. It does have water and electricity. Rita produces milk. She owns several heads of cattle. Rita would like a loan to purchase a dairy cow.
Rita's parents help her but the family does not have a comfortable living situation, so Rita would like your help. She certainly enjoys good health.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Afila

texts.en:
Afila is a 61-year-old married woman with two kids. She is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) and lives with her family in the Bilasuvar region.
Afila is a farmer. She is growing fruits and vegetables in her garden. Her son always helps her in this business. She is a laborer woman and has 10 years’ experience in this business.
Her monthly income from this business is 120 manat, but it is not enough for her family.
For this reason she needs a loan to buy seeds, new sorts of trees, and some medicine for herself.
She hopes lenders help her to increase her business. It is her first loan. She has applied for 1500 AZN. Please help her.

loans.use: to buy seeds, new sorts of trees, and some medicine for herself.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman and has two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at a rental that has electricity and piped water. She has operated a tailoring business for the past four years. She makes suits for women and men. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en: Kalsoom is a 45-year-old married woman. She has seven children. She has been running a cloth trade business with her husband (also shown in photo) for many years. Her husband sells cloth to different communities and she sells in her community. They buy cloth in various fabrics in different colors and designs from the market at wholesale rates, and then sell them to the people of different communities. They have a varied customer base and are able to earn enough through their business. Now, Kalsoom has requested a loan of 55,000 PKR to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs, to attract more customers and expand their business. She expects a boost in their earnings and plans to spend the part of their profits for the betterment of their family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand their business

loans.name: Santos Adelaida

texts.es:
La Santos Adelaida vive en una comunidad de Trojes al Oriente de Honduras, es soltera su fuente principal de ingresos es el comercio.
Doña Santos Adelaida vende productos de la canasta básica familiar como ser arroz, manteca, jabón, etc. Su negocio ha crecido por la razón de que esta ubicado en un lugar estratégico para el comercio y también por la buena atención y buenos precios, solicita el préstamo para la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, huevos, café, pan, frijoles, etc.
Doña Santos Adelaida espera que esta inversión le permita salir adelante en su negocio, uno de sus sueños es que su negocio prospere.


Trojes,  Honduras -  Noviembre del 2014
texts.en:
Santos Adelaida lives in the Trojes community in the East of Honduras. She is single, and her main source of income is her shop.

Santos Adelaida sells staple goods such as rice, butter, soap etc. Her business has grown because of its strategic location, and also due to the good service and good prices. She is asking for a loan to buy rice, sugar, oil, eggs, coffee, bread, beans etc.

Santos Adelaida hopes that this investment will allow her to keep moving forwards with her business, one of her dreams is for her business to prosper.

Trojes, Honduras - November 2014

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, eggs, coffee, bread, beans etc. for her store.

loans.name: Kaneez

texts.en: Kaneez, a 54-year-old married woman, runs a small boutique at home to provide for her family. She purchases cloth from the market at low prices, sewing and then selling it to the people of her locality.  She always has a great product selection to offer, and she earns a good income that contributes to her family's well-being. To improve her business, Kaneez has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to buy a greater variety of cloth and spools of thread, lace, buttons, etc. in various colors. It will allow her to fulfill the demands of her customers on time and to boost her earnings.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety of cloth and spools of thread, lace, buttons etc. in various colors.

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en:
Tahira and her husband (also shown in the photo above) have successfully built their sewing business with the support of Kashf Foundation and Kiva's lenders. Over time they have attained a good number of customers and have been able to make a good amount of income to support their family. 

With the help of previous loans from Kiva's lenders, Tahira and her husband were able to expand their business. Currently Tahira is on her 5th loan cycle, and now she has applied for a loan of 45,000 PKR in order to buy more supplies of thread in different colors, packs of zippers, buttons etc. 

This loan will enable Tahira and her husband to increase their revenue by taking more customer orders and thereby earn more profits.

loans.use: to buy more thread in different colors, packs of zippers, buttons, etc.

loans.name: Vicenta De Los Angeles

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Florón de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Grupo de Crédito Renacer.
En este lugar vive la señora Vicenta, tiene  79 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen siete hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo es albañil y  carpintero.
Doña Vicenta es una mujer que le gusta valerse por sí misma para salir adelante, ella   tiene una tienda de víveres en su casa donde vende productos como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, frutas y legumbres, carnes, pescado, entre otras cosas, allí sus clientes consiguen de todo, por eso es que su clientela se mantiene y aumenta cada día mas,  trabaja todos los días desde las 06h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, su esposo le ayuda cuando puede, lleva más de 17 años con su tienda con la cual se ganan la vida cuando su marido no tiene trabajo.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, entre otros productos. Esta desde el inicio en el  Grupo de Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos. Sus sueños son tener buena salud.
texts.en:
In the suburb of El Florón in the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí known for many years as the city of Royal Tamarind Trees, the communal bank Renacer meets every 15 days.

Vicenta lives here. She is 79 years old and married with seven, adult, independent children. Her husband is a bricklayer and carpenter.

Vicenta is a woman who enjoys being self-sufficient to get ahead. She has a store in her home. There she sells products such as rice, sugar, oils, detergents, fruit and vegetables, meat and fish, among other things. Her clients find everything they need there, which is why she keeps up and stocks it more every day, working daily from 6:00AM until 8:00PM and sometimes later. Her husband helps her when he can. She has had her store for more than 17 years and earns a living that way, when her husband is out of work.

This loan is going to be used to stock her store. She is going to buy rice, sugar, oils and detergents, among other products. She's been part of the communal bank since it began and she likes it because of the support she receives from these loans. Her dream is to be in good health.

loans.use: buy rice, sugar, oil and detergent, among other things.

loans.name: Limbanazo Group

texts.en:
Lucy thanks Kiva lenders for the previous loan that they granted her. She used the loan to open a shop in her community. The new shop has helped her to increase her profits as she now has more customers than before, when she was operating her business from home. Lucy is now able to provide her children with food three times a day, and she is also able to pay their medical bills.

She is requesting another loan in order to buy more plates, cups and other kitchenware items to be sold in her shop.

loans.use: to buy kitchenware to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Today, this humble mother sells milk, eggs, maize and a variety of food crops. Joyce is a passionate farmer and, because of the immense knowledge she has in farming, she commands a lot of respect from other farmers in her village. Dairy farming is close to her heart and every day she wakes up to milk her cow. That makes her very proud. Although she makes profits through milk selling, Joyce lacks a proper dairy unit and she is seeking a loan to build a modern dairy unit and buy a chaff cutter. Through the loan, she will have a better time milking and feeding her cow. A good dairy unit provides a place where cows can relax and be protected from diseases that may arise because of being exposed to harsh weather conditions such as rain. Through the loan, she will also be able to buy a chaff cutter which is a mechanical device used in cutting hay into small pieces before being mixed with other forage to produce better feed for the cow. The chaff cutter also prevents the animals from rejecting any part of the food. 

Joyce believes that through this loan, her living conditions will change because she is going to have an increase in milk production. She will save money that she used to spend on treating her cows because she lacked a good dairy unit. Joyce waits for your kindness.

Female small-scale farmers dominate the agricultural landscape in most production environments in Kenya, yet they constitute the majority of rural actors locked in socio-cultural structures that limit their agricultural productivity, efficiency and effectiveness at all points across the value chain. Key examples are entrenched inequities in access to productive land, limited access to credit, poor access to markets, extension services and agricultural technologies relevant to their needs. Kiva lenders, the above picture presents Joyce who started farming 10 years ago on a small inherited piece of land in Kiplombe, a remote village in the Eldoret area of Kenya.

loans.use: To build a modern dairy unit and buy a chaff cutter.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Placidie

texts.en: Placidie is 24 years old, married and has two children, ages 1 and 4, who are not yet in school. She sells livestock and has been in a business for four years. With the loan, she would like to buy more sheep to resell. The profits from the business will be used improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more sheep to resell

loans.name: Sonia Esperanza

texts.es:
Sonia de 59 años de edad, está casada y tiene cuatro hijos, solo una vive con ella, estudió hasta 6° grado de educación básica, su esposo es agricultor, solo él y su hija viven con ella.

Sonia desde muy joven trabajo en la agricultora, pero desde que se casó se dedicó únicamente a esta actividad con su esposo para sacar adelante a su familia, la parcela de siembra está ubicada cerca de su casa. Solicita el préstamo para comprar bloque, cemento, hierro y otros materiales para mejorar su casa. Sueña con tener su casa como la soñó, que su hija sea una persona de bien y seguir trabajando duro.
texts.en:
Sonia is 59, married with 4 children.  One of her children lives with her, she studied up to 6th grade of basic education. Her husband works in agriculture, she lives with him and their daughter.

From a very young age Sonia started working in agriculture, when she married she only worked in this activity with her husband to get their family ahead.  The piece of land is located close to their house.  She requests a loan to buy  brick, cement, iron and other materials to make improvements to her house.  Her wishes are to have her dream house, have a good daughter and continue working hard.

loans.use: to buy brick, cement, iron and other materials.

loans.name: Kyarusozi S&c Group

texts.en:
Muhammad is a 53-year-old married man with 10 children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. Of all his children, only four attend school. His business is operating a drug shop of human drugs, and he is also involved in poultry farming to generate more income, having started the business because it falls under his professional circle. 

Muhammad has asked for a loan to buy human drugs and other medical facilities to use in his drug shop. He is a member of a group where each member guarantees the other to get a loan.

loans.use: To buy human drugs and other medical facilities to use in his drug shop.

loans.name: Jerturde

texts.en: Jerturde is 34 years old and  married with two children, ages 8 and 12 years, and both in school.  She has a shop and has been in business for five years. With the loan, she would like to buy more rice, beans and maize to resell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more rice, beans and maize to resell.

loans.name: Disan

texts.en:
Disan is a hard-working married man with three children living in Kamwenge Uganda. He operates a stationery shop and also teaches to earn extra income. He started this business to educate his children. He hopes to become rich. His main challenge is price fluctuation of the goods he deals in. 

He is requesting a loan to buy more stock like textbooks, papers, pens and boxes of chalk for sale.

loans.use: to buy more stock like textbooks, papers, pens and boxes of chalk for sale.

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Samaila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Musa, Bello and Harisu.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Samaila would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Samaila can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Samaila  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms; eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Idi

texts.en: Idi is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Idi joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Isuhu, Rahab and Sera.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Idi would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Idi can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Idi  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are well educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms; eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Zatonse Group

texts.en:
Elina is 45 years old and looks after seven of her children and one orphan. She sells fish in her community, which she buys from Lake Malawi. She started this business in order to financially support her family and to reduce her family’s level of poverty. 

Intending to expand her business she will use the loan to buy more stock, so as to increase her profits. She hopes to open a shop one day, and dreams of educating her children. Elina is now self-reliant; she no longer depends on her husband.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her business.

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe BADEGNA ont en moyenne 42 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à MEDINE l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des produits divers.
Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe BADEGNA sont à leur 6ème prêt solidaire. AWA, 1ère femme  à gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 20Litres d’huile, 5 paniers de tomate, 5 boîtes de craie, 2 boîtes Bic, 1 carton de biscuit, 2 cartons de bonbon, 20Kgs de sucre et 10Kgs de lait en poudre. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the BADEGNA group are women who average 42 years of age and three children each. They all live in extended traditional families in MEDINE, a district of SAN/SEGOU (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

These women share ties of kinship. They buy and sell miscellaneous merchandise. 

Having repaid their previous loans without incident, they are now in their 6th group loan cycle. AWA, first from the left in the group photo, plans to use her loan to buy 20 liters of oil, 5 baskets of tomatoes, 5 boxes of chalk, 2 boxes of Bic products, 1 carton of cookies, 2 cartons of candy, 20 kg of sugar and 10 kg of powdered milk. She buys her stock from local wholesalers, and she sells to a clientele consisting of men and women, cash or credit. 

Awa expects to earn an average monthly profit of 20,000FCFA, which she will use to pay for healthcare, food, clothing and tuition. Any remainder will be reinvested in her activity.

loans.use: to buy various merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en:
Jean Paul is 41 years old. He is married with 4 children between 5 and 20 years old; all of them go to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for 18 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 44 years old. He is married with 7 children aged between 1 and 22 years, 4 of whom go to school. 

Innocent has been farming for 21 years. He will use this loan from Kiva's lenders to buy fertilizer to grow maize which he will then sell. The profits will be used to pay his employees.


As of 2009, the agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans. However, despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow maize which he will sell.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 48 years old. He is married with four children aged between seven and 23 years; all of them go to school. Joseph has farmed for 15 years and will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and grow and sell maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his employees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and grow and sell maize

loans.name: Patrice

texts.en:
Patrice is 38 years old. He is married with three children between two and six years old. Two of his children go to school. Patrice has farmed for 13 years and will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize. The profits from his business will be used to pay his workers. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow and sell  maize

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 55 years old and a married man with children who are eight 8 and 31 years old. Both children attend school. Jean has farmed for 19 years and will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize. The profits from his business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize

loans.name: Ma. Teresa

texts.en:
Ma. Teresa is a married woman with 1 child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Ma. Teresa is 35 years old now.

Ma. Teresa has a seaweed business in the Philippines, a business she has been running for 1 year. She has requested a loan of 5,500 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to buy other farm supplies for her seaweed production business.

In the future, Ma. Teresa would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy other farm supplies for her seaweed production business.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a woman with a big heart, and her tenderness and her love for farming exceed all limits. She is a wise farmer who is respected by her neighbors and fellow farmers as a mentor. She farms a small plot of land in the green, lush hills of Eldoret, which is in the Rift valley region of Kenya. Sarah is happily married and is blessed with three lovely children. For the past 12 years, she has been involved in mixed farming, and she grows maize and vegetables. She also has dairy cows. Sarah has been able to provide nutritious food for her family. She earns profits selling a variety of food crops, but she is faced with a challenge of delivering the produce in a timely manner to the market. This challenge has not made her give up, and she states: “I have to do something for my family." Sarah joined Juhudi Kilimo, which is a microfinance institution that assists aspiring women like her. She requests a loan from Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva lenders to buy a motorbike. Sarah is from a remote village that has poor roads, and transporting her produce to the market has been a challenge. She has suffered many losses of perishable products (milk, vegetables, and tomatoes), which require timely delivery to the market. This loan will help Sarah to achieve her dream and reach her goals. Accessing a financial solution for women in Kenya is an uphill battle, but Sarah feels relieved to know that there are institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva that help women to gain respect and equality among their male counterparts. The benefits of this loan are astronomical because Sarah will never suffer losses due to delay in delivering produce to the market. She will increase her sales volume because she will be able to transport more goods to the market. Her income will increase. Sarah is a woman who is making a change for herself and for others in the community because she intends to employ someone to ride the motorbike and help with farm work. Sarah will use the loan to improve her living conditions and ensure a secure future for her children and grandchildren to come.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is 44 years old and married, with four children.

Lina works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and she has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy items to sell, like canned goods, shampoo, and beverages.

Lina has borrowed and paid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Lina aspires to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell, like canned goods, shampoo, and beverages.

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne, in search of a promising future and good opportunities to get ahead, decided to start farming. According to her, farming will give her everything she has always dreamed of.

Anne is a smallholder farmer from Eldoret in the Rift Valley region of Kenya. She owns a five-acre farm where she practices mixed farming. On the farm she keeps dairy animals and grows maize and vegetables. She has seven years of experience in farming. Anne is seeking a loan to expand her horticulture farm. She is very hardworking and determined to increase her farm's output. 

Loans for smallholder farmers with little irregular income and no solid collateral are hard to come by in Kenya. Few organizations such as Juhudi Kilimo support farmers like Anne. Through a group of ten members called Toror Bonet self-help group, Anne has access to income-generating asset loans from Juhudi, which use the group-based savings as collateral. According to Juhudi Kilimo, horticulture represents an opportunity for reducing poverty through income generation among smallholder farmers, both unskilled and semi-skilled. In the past, African women used to stay at home and look after the household. Juhudi Kilimo facilitates loans that empower smallholder farmers like Anne because the institution believes that women too are actively involved in various segments of the horticultural industry.

loans.use: To expand her horticulture farm

loans.name: Diphas

texts.en:
Diphas is a hard-working farmer from a cell in Nyakayojo, Mbarara district.  He is 40 years, married and has five children in their teens.
He has been depending on agriculture since his 20s to earn a living. His farming has yielded him a good income and he has managed to construct some small rentals to boost his income.
However, he has a very big expenditure paying his children's school fees. He approached UGAFODE for a small loan of 2,000,000 UGX to help him complete his rentals. So far, he has generated high levels of income and hopes he will do even better to uplift the education standards of his children to a sustainable level. He is hard working and resilient.

loans.use: To buy construction materials like cement, plaster and paint

loans.name: Isiyaku Maidawa

texts.en: Isiyaku Maidawa is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Isiyaku Maidawa joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Iliya, Isuhu and Isiya.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Isiyaku Maidawa would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Isiyaku Maidawa can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Isiyaku Maidawa spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are well educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for his child school fees and uniforms; eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices after harvest

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a maize farmer from Chino village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, John would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, John can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. John, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices after harvest

loans.name: Alh. Adamu

texts.en: Alh.Adamu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Alh. Adamu would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alh. Adamu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.  Alh. Adamu expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home and in the long run, become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices after harvest

loans.name: Markus

texts.en: Markus is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Markus joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Ishaku and Ibrahim.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Markus would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Markus can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Markus spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are well educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms; eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Abdullahi

texts.en: Abdullahi is a maize farmer from Mabuga village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Abdullahi would have had to sell his maize  at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Abdullahi can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Abdullahi, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Ummaru

texts.en: Ummaru is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ummaru would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ummaru can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked about his goals, Ummaru expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a Babban Gona maize farmer. 

In the past, because he needed to pay his pressing expenses, Michael would typically have sold his maize soon after harvest, but when prices were lowest. However, now that he is a member of Babban Gona, with their support and this loan, Michael can store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more.

When asked about his goals, Michael expressed a desire to not only use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, but also, in the long run, ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy his family food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 45 years old and a married man with children who are and ten and 14 years old. Both children attend school. Innocent has farmed for 18 years and will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize. The profits from his business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize

loans.name: Valens

texts.en:
Valens is 52 years old and married with children who are seven and 25 years old. Both children attend school. Valens has been a farmer for 15 years and will use his Kiva loan to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize. The profits from his business will be used to pay his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow and sell maize

loans.name: Graceous

texts.en:
Graceous is married and is a second-time borrower at UGAFODE Microfinance. He has seven children and is also taking care of one child who is an orphan. He lives in a rural area with his family. He runs a retail shop business and also farms. He started his business in 2001.

He works 7 days a week and 15 hours per day and started this business to supplement his family income. He acquired this loan to re-stock his retail shop and be able to serve his customers in this festival season. He says that his clients are residents and people from the surrounding area.

His future hope is to expand his business, and the challenges he faces are lack of enough capital and seasonality of his goods. He describes himself as an honest and hardworking man. He encourages lenders to always offer the best customer care services and to also increase publicity to make everyone aware of the services offered.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in his retail shop.

loans.name: Straton

texts.en:
Straton is 48 years old, married, and has 2 children who are 3 and 21 years old. Both of his children attend school. 

Straton has been farming for 19 years. He plans to use this loan from Kiva's lenders to buy fertilizer to grow maize which he will then sell. The profits from the sale of this maize will be used to pay his workers.

As of 2009, the agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans. Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. 

For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow maize which he will sell.

loans.name: Jonas

texts.en:
Jonas is 39 years old. He is married with one 5-year-old child, who goes to school. 

Jonas has been farming for 11 years now. He will use this loan from Kiva's lenders in order to buy fertilizer to grow maize. He plans to sell the maize and use the profits to pay his employees.

As of 2009, the agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans. 

Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. 

Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva's lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow maize which he will sell.

loans.name: Roger

texts.es: Roger vive en concubinato y tiene dos hijos, el cliente y su familia viven en la comunidad de Ajllata, donde las condiciones climáticas son cambiantes. La familia vive en una casa de adobe que es propia, la casa tiene luz y agua.  Roger se dedica a la produccion de leche junto a su pareja y tambien trabaja como albañil pero para eso viaja hasta Achacachi Roger quiere una vaca lechera para incrementar su produccion de leche Roger y su familia gozan de buena salud y el cliente esta seguro de hacer crecer su negocio por eso espera que puedan ayudarle
texts.en: Roger lives with his girlfriend and has two children. They live in the community of Ajilata, which has a variable climate. The family lives in their own adobe home. The home has electricity and water. Roger and his girlfriend produce milk. He also works as a bricklayer, but to do this he travels to Acacachi. Roger wants a dairy cow to increase his milk production. He and his family enjoy good health and Roger is certain that his business will grow, so he hopes you can help him.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu is a married woman with 6 children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Marichu is 35 years old, and 5 of her children are in school.

Marichu has been running her seaweed business in the Philippines for 1 year. She is requesting a 7,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to buy other farm supplies for her seaweed production business.

In the future, Marichu would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy other farm supplies for her seaweed production business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 38 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Marilyn is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Marilyn has been in this business for four years, and she earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
This is Hellen, who is a woman of character and good intentions and who has goals of progressing and going forward with her family. She is a mother of two and is from Eldoret, a remote town in Kenya. She has spent the last five years of her life farming. She sells eggs, milk, and vegetables produced on her farm. She also engages in a personal business to make ends meet.

Hellen is a go-getter and has a great desire to succeed in life. Of all the activities she involves herself in, poultry farming is closest to her heart. She enjoys waking up every morning to go and feed her animals. She is so close with her animals that she has nicknamed one of them “Kipara,” meaning "no feathers on the head."

Hellen wants to take full advantage of poultry farming as a profitable business venture. She would like to expand her poultry business, but the biggest challenge she faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES, which she will use to buy additional poultry. With your loan, Hellen will be able to expand the poultry section on her farm. This will generate enough income to repay the loan, and she will also be able to save extra money.

Hellen is very concerned about her children’s education, so profits from farming will go to pay their school fees. Hellen dreams of a secure future for her children. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Nenita is 49 years old, and three of her children are in school.

Nenita has a food vending business in the Philippines. Nenita requested a PHP 7,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Nenita has been in this business for two years. In the future, Nenita would like to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali Alh. is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ali Alh. would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ali Alh. can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked about his goals, Ali Alh. expressed a desire to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and in the long run, make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en: Adamu is a maize farmer from Kwari village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Adamu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs.
