With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Adamu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Adamu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure his children are well educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Magaji

texts.en: Magaji is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Magaji joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Yasir, Jamila and Bashir. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Magaji would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Magaji can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.  Magaji spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms; eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Alh. Haruna

texts.en: Alh. Haruna is a maize farmer from Kwakwa village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Alh. Haruna would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alh. Haruna can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Alh. Haruna, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy his family food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Markus

texts.en: Markus is a maize farmer from Yan Gwari village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Markus would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Markus can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Markus, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en: Alhaji is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Alhaji joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Rabi, Balaraba and Inna.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Alhaji would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alhaji can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Alhaji  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms; eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Scott

texts.en:
Scott is the sole owner of Eagle Doors, a specialty contractor for doors and hardware installations in Florida. He worked in this industry for several years before starting Eagle Doors five years ago. The majority of his business comes through word of mouth and referrals – a testament to his focus on quality craftsmanship and customer service.

Scott's work supports himself, his fiancee, and two children.

Scott is a returning Accion East client. His first loan helped him better manage his payroll expenses for his five employees. This loan will continue to help Scott build his credit and allow him to purchase materials for incoming large work orders.

loans.use: to pay for doors and hardware supplies, while helping rebuild his credit.

loans.name: Azucena Margarita

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Florón de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Grupo de Crédito Renacer.
En este lugar vive la señora Azucena, tiene  50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene cinco hijos, cuatro  mayores de edad y uno de 7 años el cual estudia en escuela y es el único que aun vive con ella. Su esposo tiene una vulcanizadora.
Doña Azucena es una mujer que le gusta trabajar y con su labor ayudarle a su marido a salir adelante, ella tienen un negocio en el cual vende tubos, llantas, aros y otros repuestos de carros, ella aprovecha que su esposo tiene una vulcanizadora y con la ayuda de su primer crédito comenzó con su negocio, ella vende productos nuevos y reencauchados, trabaja de lunes a sábados al igual que su marido, ya son mas de 18 años que lleva en esta labor la cual le permite salir adelante.
Este crédito lo va a emplear para comprar llantas, aros  y tubos. Esta desde el inicio  en el Grupo de Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y sin tantos requisitos. Sus sueños un negocio mucho más rápido y estructurado.
texts.en:
In the suburb of El Florón of the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, known for years as the city of the Royal Tamarind Trees, the communal group Renacer meets every 15 days.

Azucena lives here. She is 50 years old, married and has five children, four of whom are independent and one who is 7 years old, is in school and is the only one who lives with her. Her husband has a tire repair shop.

Azucena is a woman who enjoys working and with her work, helping her husband make a go of it. She has a business in which she sell tires, hub caps, tire tubes and other car parts. With her first loan, she started her business by taking advantage of the fact that her husband owned a tire repair shop. She sells new and refurbished products. She works Monday to Saturday, the same as her husband. She's had this business for more than 18 years and it has helped them get ahead.

This loan will be used to buy tires, hub caps and tire tubes. She's been with the communal bank since its inception and she likes that the loans are quick and accessible. Her dream is to have a more efficient and structured business.

loans.use: buy tires, hub caps and tire tubes.

loans.name: Venacie

texts.en:
Venancie is 42 years old, married and the mother of eight children who range in age from one to 24 years old. Five of her children are in school, and she has worked for the last 15 years as a farmer. She has requested a loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers so she can grow maize to sell.  

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow and sell maize.

loans.name: Ana Vilma

texts.es: Ana de 44 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo, ella se dedica a la crianza de pollos desde hace 5 años y los comercializa en los diferentes mercados, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de alimentos y vitaminas para los pollos para poder continuar con la crianza y asi tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en: Ana is 44 years old and lives in a house of her own together with her husband.  She's raised chickens for a living for the past 5 years and sells them at various markets.  She's requesting a loan to buy food and vitamins for her chickens so she can continue raising them and increase her income.

loans.use: buy food and vitamins for her chickens

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en:
Rosette is a first-time borrower with UGAFODE Microfinance. She was motivated to borrow from UGAFODE after she saw her fellow villagers progressing in business. And when she asked their secret, they told her they had been borrowing from UGAFODE to sustain their businesses. 

Being a cattle keeper, she wishes to take a loan so she can buy more stock of young bulls that she will fatten on hay and then sell for a profit. 

She is hard-working and resilient and appreciates the services provided by UGAFODE Microfinance.

loans.use: to buy cows for fattening and resale.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is aged 38 years with a family of thee children aged 11, 9, and 4 years. Only two attend school. He ventures in agriculture, a business he started in 1999.

He was given a loan of 2,000,000 (two million shillings) to invest in his agriculture business. He buys and sells corn, millet, and beans. He will buy more of these and also increase his sales and profit.

He is affected by the fluctuating prices of the products, but above all thanks the Kiva lenders for the support.

(James is pictured with the UGAFODE credit officer, left to right.)

loans.use: to buy corn and beans to sell.

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip is a married man with one child, who attends school and is under his care. He lives at a rental house that has electricity but no piped water.

For over three years, he has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door to door and from home to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business.

With the loan of KES 20,000 that he is requesting, he wants to purchase a bale of kids’ wear clothes for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of kids' wear clothes for resale.

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es:
Miguel de 48 años de edad,  está casado y tiene cuatro hijos pero solo dos viven con él, no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar,  su esposa es ama de casa, solo ella y sus dos hijos dependen de él.

Miguel es agricultor desde hace 35 años, aprendió esta actividad gracias a sus padres que siempre le inculcaron el hábito de trabajo. La parcela de siembra está ubicada a 4 kilómetros de su casa se traslada caminando, la única dificultad es llevar los insumos agrícolas porque el camino está muy malo, por lo general trabaja 6 horas al día desde las 6:00 am.

Solicita el préstamo para pagar el alquiler de la tierra donde cultiva y asegurar la parcela para la próxima temporada de siembra. Miguel espera algún día comprar su propio terreno para trabajar y que sus dos hijos terminen su carrera en la universidad.
texts.en:
Miguel, age 48, is married and has four children, but only two of them live with him. He did not have the opportunity to study. His wife is a housewife. She and their two children depend on him.
Miguel has been a farmer for 35 years. He learned this work thanks to his parents, who always strove to give him a good work ethic. His farmland is located 4 kilometres from his home and he gets there on foot. His only challenge is bringing the agricultural supplies there because the road is very bad. He usually works 6 hours a day, starting at 6:00 am.
He is requesting this loan to pay the rent on his farmland in order to secure the land for the next sowing season. Miguel hopes one day to buy his own plot of land to work, and that his children will finish their university studies.

loans.use: to pay the rent on the land where he farms.

loans.name: Novelita

texts.en:
Novelita is a married woman with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Novelita is 26 years old.

Novelita has a fishing business in the Philippines. Novelita requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing nets and other fishing materials.

Novelita has been in this business for four years. In the future, Novelita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and other fishing materials

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla is a married woman with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Perla is 43 years old, and three of her children are in school.

Perla has a food vending business in the Philippines. Perla requested a PHP 7,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Perla has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Perla would like to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is a woman with one child. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. She is 29 years old and has one child in school.

Lourdes has a direct-selling business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy more products to sell.

Lourdes has been in this business for three years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more products to sell.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
This is Agnes. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in the year 2013 to benefit from trainings on enterprise development and financial management. She is 57 years old and blessed with four children. Her economic activity is vegetable and dairy farming. 

She is borrowing a loan to buy fertilizer and dairy feed to help improve crop yield and the cows’ milk production. She hopes to get more income that will ensure food security in her household. Agnes is grateful to Kiva and all lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and dairy feed to help improve on crop yield and dairy cows' productivity thus increasing income that will ensure food security.

loans.name: Flavia

texts.en:
Flavia is a business lady from Kyeitagi Kiruhura district. She lost her husband 10 years ago and has been struggling ever since to support her five children who are all in school. Thanks to her strong physique, at the age of 45 years, Flavia can run all her small projects by herself.
She is a housewife with no formal employment as she never studied. She has a banana plantation from which she sells matooke to earn a small amount of money to service the basic needs of her home…
She also has a poultry business which generates money to pay the tuition of her eldest daughter who is studying at university in Mbarara, Uganda.
Because of high competition and the demand for quality products, and her need to educate her children, Flavia finds herself needing more capital to inject into her business. Her birds need quality feed as they are laying eggs but she doesn't have enough money to buy the feed.
She has approached the UGAFODE branch in Mbarara requestinga loan of UGX.5,000,000 to meet this need. Since she has always repaid her loans well, we believe she will do well with this one. She is very grateful for the support.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis and his family have decided to purchase a 12 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester in order to reduce the operating costs of their small farm, of which gas is an important part. Through the biodigester, they will be able to take advantage of the organic waste produced by their cows, to produce their own biogas and biofertilizer, therefore progressively displacing non-renewable and expensive propane gas and agrochemical fertilizers. 

In addition to reducing their expenses, the yield of the corn they cultivate will increase in a natural way, as they spread the nutrient-rich and organic fertilizer on their field. Luis is pictured on the day his biodigester was installed. This loan represents 20% of the total cost of the biodigester, the remaining part is being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to purchase a 12 m3 Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Gladys Maribel

texts.es:
Gladys de 37 años de edad, está acompañada y tiene dos hijos, su pareja es agricultor de granos básicos solo él y sus hijos viven con ella. Gladys es comerciante, tiene un chalet en la escuela de la comunidad desde hace 3 años, la idea de este negocio surgió como una alternativa para ayudar a su pareja con los gastos de la casa y cuando este no trabaja en el campo se involucra en el negocio.

Solicita el préstamo para comprar productos para su chalet, golosinas bebidas, alimentos que ella prepara y  hacer unas reparaciones al chalet, para el inicio del año escolar el siguiente año 2015.
Le gustaría tener un negocio con mayor capacidad y con él poder cubrir los gastos de la familia.
texts.en:
Gladys is 37 years old, she is married and has two children, her partner is a farmer of basic grains.  Only her husband and children live with her.  Gladys is a merchant, she has a spot in the community school, she's had it for 3 years.  The idea for this business came up as an alternative to help his partner with home expenses and when he isn't working in agriculture he helps with the business.

She requests the loan to buy products for her store, snacks, drinks, food that she prepares and fix certain parts of the store to have it ready for the 2015 school year.
She would like to have a bigger business and be able to cover her family expenses.

loans.use: to buy products for her store, snacks, drinks, food that she prepares and fix certain parts of the store

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 57 years old, married man with 15 and 30 year old children who attend school. He has farmed for 22 years and will use the loan from Kiva, to buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.
------------------------
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell maize.

loans.name: Miguel

texts.en:
Miguel sells books for a living. He is also studying graphic design and engineering.  Miguel attends night classes. He needs a loan to buy a computer to use for school..

Miguel is single and has no kids but he helps his mother, and he will appreciate the help you can give him.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney is 37 years old. He is married with one seven year old child who attends school. He has farmed for 19 years and will use the loan from Kiva, to buy fertilizers to grow maize to sell them. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his employees.
------------------------
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow maize.

loans.name: Nienta Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogamiques, les sept (07) membres du groupe  Nienta ont en moyenne 34 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à  Kalaban-coura l’un des quartiers de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu à Kalaban-coura. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de, produits cosmétiques, habits, jus, macaronis, fruits et restauration. Dans l’intention d’accroitre leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Sadio (femme assise à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse de produits cosmétiques. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  3 cartons de pommades, 10 paquets de mèches et 2 cartons de parfums à Bamako. La revente se fait en détails à Kalaban-coura à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Sadio compte avoir avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et satisfaire les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Nienta group are women who are mainly married in monogamous households. They average 34 years of age and three children each. They all live in Kalaban-coura, a district of Bamako, and they know one another as neighbors and through the income-generating activities 
they conduct in the village. They practice small trade involving cosmetic products, clothing, juice, pasta, fruits, and restaurant services. 

To bolster their working capital, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance organization. This is their third group loan cycle. 

Mrs. Sadio (sitting at the far left) is a major reseller of cosmetic products. She plans to use her loan to buy 3 cartons of pomade, 10 packages of hair extensions, and 2 cartons of perfume in Bamako. She retails her stock in Kalaban-coura to a clientele composed mainly of women.  

With this loan, Mrs. Sadio expects to earn an average monthly profit of 100,000FCFA, which she will use to provide for her household and to reinvest in her activity.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products.

loans.name: Jay Shakti Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
All Hamidaben has ever wanted is a decent life and the means to afford it. She is shown standing at the center of the picture. Her intention of starting her own private small business was to reduce the burden placed on her husband and to ensure at least two square meals a day for her family. While she has been successful in her endeavors to a certain extent, her current monthly income of just 3,000 India Rupees (INR) from her business could be improved. 

Hamidaben is the owner of a provisional business in Surendranagar, Gujarat and needs significant expansion to bring in more profits. She wants to buy more oil tins for this purpose, which will net her an increased enterprise income of 5000 rupees. Part of this will go towards almost doubling her income, and the rest she will invest in the further growth of her business, with the objective of achieving self-sustainability. A stalling factor in her expansion plans is her lack of access to capital.

Since local banks do not cater to the microfinancing that women entrepreneurs like Hamidaben need, she has approached Milaap’s field partner Prayas. Under the guidance of Prayas, Hamidaben has formed a joint liability group called ‘Jay Shakti Mahila Mandal’ with four other women who are all residents of Surendranagar and are involved in their own small-scale businesses. A loan amount of 100,000 rupees will be used by Hamidaben to buy oil tins, Janakben and Manjuben to buy clothes for their clothing shops, Bhavanbahen to buy fruits for her business, and Rizvana to buy chemicals for her chemical selling enterprise.

loans.use: To buy oil tins for the growth of her provisions business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to invest in: galvanized sheets, wood and nails to construct a house.

loans.name: Santa Martha Group

texts.es: Al grupo solidario Santa Martha lo integran tres mujeres emprendedoras, coordinado por la señora Jazmina de 33 años de edad, acompañada, se dedica a la venta hecha y venta de hojuelas, son un producto que la población demanda, comercializándolos en su las calles de su municipio y en la capital, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de quintal de harina, azúcar, aceite, flete de leña e instrumentos para mejorar la calidad de los productos ofrecidos, es el vigésimo segundo crédito que ADIM le brinda el financiamiento para su negocio y ha demostrado ser una persona responsable, ella asegura que uno de los logros obtenidos es el aumento de la producción de hojuelas. El resto de los integrantes son las señoras Lidia de 39 años de edad dedicada a la realizar costuras de artesanía de en su domicilio desde hace veinte años.
texts.en: The Santa Martha community bank has three members, all women, led by Jazmina, the group's coordinator,  Jazmina, 33, is married and operates a business making and selling hojuelas, a local dish much in demand here.  She works as a street vendor, selling hojuelas from street to street.  She is applying for a loan that she will use to buy the supplies she need--flour, sugar, cooking oil, firewood, etc.--to ensure the quality of her hojuelas.  This is Jazmina's twenty-second ADIM loan and she has demonstrated that she is a reliable borrower.  The investment will help her to increase her production and carry on her business.  The other members of the community bank are Lidia, 39, who has a crafts business and María, 35, who has a food sales business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her food sales business.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is aged 39 years with four children, two of them attending school. He grows potatoes on a large scale to improve his standard of living. He is greatly affected by the fluctuating prices of the agricultural produce.

He was given a loan amounting to UGX 1,000,000 (one million shillings) to work on his business to buy tomato seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides. This will help to produce good-quality tomatoes, which will increase his sales and income.

Pictured are Paul and the UGAFODE credit officer (left to right in his tomato garden).

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Jay Rakhodada Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
All her life, Hansaben (center, in the picture) has had to think twice before investing in basic necessities. Even now, with her own functioning business, her financial situation isn’t good enough to raise her four children in a comfortable environment. Along with her husband, Hansaben manages to earn just about 14,000 India Rupees (INR) every month. She is involved in a small scale enterprise selling showpieces that are mostly made of glass. She buys her delicate and intricate inventory from the wholesale market in Surendranagar, Gujarat, and sells it to local customers at a profit. She saves her entire income of 4000 rupees that she earns from her efforts. With two pre-school aged children and two primary school-going children, though, she needs to save a lot more than this.

Not one to be bogged down by difficulties, her plans for expanding her business pushed her to seek the help of Milaap and its field partner, Prayas. With appropriate guidance from the two organizations, Hansaben has formed a joint liability group with four other women in her community. While two of her group members are involved in a scrap business, the other two are involved in embroidery and selling showpieces, respectively. A loan of 100,000 rupees will give them a well-deserved opportunity to grow their businesses, diversify their clientele, and grow profits. Your loan will help develop their microenterprises into self-sustaining businesses that ensure financial stability for their families and access to education for their children. 

Having had no opportunity to attend school due to her own parents’ poverty, Hansaben especially feels strongly about education. She knows how important it is to learn to read, write, and have a college degree. She believes that these factors will open opportunities and choices, which she did not have, for her children to uplift themselves. She is determined to make a success out of this opportunity. To begin with, she will increase her profits by 6000 rupees per month, saving part of it and reinvesting the rest into her business, eventually making it self-sustaining. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy greater varieties of inventory in bulk and grow her microenterprise of selling glass showpieces.

loans.name: Fátima  Del Socorro

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Florón de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Grupo de Crédito Renacer.
En este lugar vive la señora Fátima, tiene 59 años de edad, es madre soltera de  tres hijos mayores de edad, uno de ellos aun vive con ella.
Doña Fátima es una mujer que le gusta valerse por sí misma para conseguir sus propios recursos y salir adelante, ella se dedica a la venta de productos Avon (artículos de belleza, cosméticos, cremas, perfumería y bisuterías). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, sale en sus momentos libres a vender sus productos, ella deja a crédito y cobra cada ocho o quince días, lleva dos años dedicada a esta actividad con la cual sale adelante. 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar cosméticos, cremas  y productos de belleza. Lleva dos años  en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con  los créditos empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son seguir adelante.
texts.en:
In the suburb of El Florón in the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, known for many years as the city of the Royal Tamarind Trees, the communal group Renacer meets every 15 days.

This is where Fátima lives. She is 59 years old, a single mother of three independent children, of whom one still lives with her.

Fátima enjoys being self-sufficient, by finding her own recourses and getting ahead. She sells Avon products (beauty supplies, cosmetics, creams, perfumes and jewelry). She sells door-to-door, going out to sell on her free time, taking orders on credit and collecting every 8 to 15 days. For 2 years she's been running this business and making a go of it.

She will use this loan to buy cosmetics, creams and beauty products. She's been with the communal group for 2 years and is very happy as the loans have helped her start her business. Her dream is to continue making a go of it.

loans.use: buy cosmetics, creams and beauty products.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en:
Iliya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Iliya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Hamidu, Bala, and Sihionah.

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Iliya would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Iliya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked, Iliya spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to pay for his childrens' school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Rhoda is 27 years old, and three of her children are in school.

Rhoda has a fishing business in the Philippines. Rhoda requested a PHP 6,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing nets and other fishing materials.

Rhoda has been in this business for two years. In the future, Rhoda would like to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and other fishing materials

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en:
Saratu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. She joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Inusa, Mika and Danlami.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Saratu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Saratu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Saratu spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for child school fees and uniforms, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Yakubu Manja

texts.en:
Yakubu Manja is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, he would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yakubu Manja can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked about his goals, Yakubu Manja expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Marleni

texts.es: Marleni: Es una mujer cordial, originaria de Waspam, tiene 38 años de edad, madre soltera, de una hija de 14 años, que cursa su segundo año de secundaria. Por razones laborales desde hace 6 años se trasladó a la ciudad de Bilwi. Cuenta con una experiencia de cinco años de ser docente de primaria. Debido a la poca fuente de ingreso del hogar y con el propósito de brindarle a su hija un momento de felicidad, solicita financiamiento para celebrarle los 15 años, con una pequeña reunión familiar y amigos de su hija en su vivienda de minifalda de zinc y madera. Su  sueño es tener una finca para sembrar tubérculos, granos básicos y disponer de otra fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Marleni is a friendly woman from Waspam. She is 38 and a single mother with a 14-year-old daughter who is in the second grade of secondary school. For work reasons, six years ago Marleni moved to the city of Bilwi. She has five years' experience as a primary teacher.
Because of her low household income, and with the goal of providing her daughter with a moment of happiness, she is requesting a loan to celebrate her dauther's 15th birthday with a small party with family and friends in her home, which is made of zinc and wood.
Her dream is to have a farm to plant tubers and grains in order to have another source of income.

loans.use: to celebrate her daughter's 15th birthday.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Juan is a tailor and pays rent in a building where he has a room and a kitchen. In this room, he also has a small workshop where he makes backpacks and brief cases which he sells. He is requesting a loan to buy cloth, zippers, and straps to make more backpacks because January is a good month to sell these items. Juan is a happily married man with two children who are six and two years old. He is grateful for the help he is receiving from Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy cloth, zippers, and straps to make more backpacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new cleaning equipment

loans.name: Cristina Elizabeth

texts.es: Cristina es una mujer de 50 años de edad que habita en vivienda propia junto a sus 2 hijos de 32 y 17 años de edad, por lo que se siente muy feliz de haber logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos como madre soltera. Ella se gana la vida con la elaboración de prendas de vestir actividad que realiza en su vivienda desde hace 8 años por lo que cuenta con muchos clientes que solicitan sus productos. Cristina desea construir una vivienda de lámina y para ello solicita un crédito a FUSAI que le permita invertir en: lámina galvanizada, madera y clavos para construir una vivienda de lámina.
texts.en: Cristina is 50, she lives in her own house with her two children ages 32 and 17.  She is happy to have been able to get her children ahead as a single mother.  She earns a living making dress clothes, activity she performs from her house when she started 8 years ago.  She has many customers that request her products.  Cristina wants to build a house made of galvanized tin sheets and request a loan to FUSAI to allows her to invest in galvanized tin sheets, wood and nails to build the house.

loans.use: to invest in galvanized tin sheets, wood and nails to build a house.

loans.name: Bienvenido Jr.

texts.en:
Bienvenido Jr. is 34 years old and lives in Tangub City. He is married and has two children. He owns and manages a retail store, selling specialized auto and motor parts, products, and accessories. This is his way of earning a living and raising his family. He has had this business for 15 years and earns PHP 700, daily.

Bienvenido Jr. has requested a loan to pay for additional stock for his store. He has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Bienvenido Jr. hopes that his business will grow and continue, for the benefit of his family.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock for his auto and motor parts store.

loans.name: El Esfuerzo 2 Group

texts.es:
La tranquilidad, el clima y la vista que ofrece la comunidad donde se encuentra el grupo El Esfuerzo 2 son muy relajantes. Hace un mes inició la zafra (período de corte de caña) y con ella la reactivación de la economía en la región ya que la mayoría de los habitantes de la comunidad se dedica a trabajar el campo, mientras que otros tantos tienen su propio negocio como los integrantes del grupo:

Viviana - Abarrotes
Adela - Tamales
Modesta -Pan
Laura -Mojarra
Cruz -Cosméticos
Marcela –Zapatos Por Catalogo
Felicita –Molino De Nixtamal
Maura -Abarrotes
Rosalia -Masa
Reyna -Antojitos
Ángel, Ignacio -Mojarra
Reyna -Abarrotes
Adriana -Pollo
Clara –Tortillas 

Comprar pan y revenderlo en la comunidad es la actividad que doña Modesta ha desempeñado desde hace 1 año. A partir de las 4 de la tarde acomoda su en la motocicleta, se dirige a comprar el pan y posteriormente se dedica a recorrer las calles para ofrecerlo. Al inicio de la actividad, su inversión fue muy baja pero a los pocos meses solicitó su primer préstamo a VisionFund que le permitió incrementar la cantidad de piezas que podía comprar. Actualmente, Modesta está en busca de un proveedor con quien pueda conseguir precios más accesibles. 

Modesta es madre de tres muchachos, uno de ellos es quien le ayuda a manejar la moto en sus tardes de venta. El esposos de Modesta, Félix se dedica a trabajar en el campo y la continuidad de sus actividades es muy importante para pagar los gastos familiares. Esta vez modesta necesita comprar un nuevo canasto y más pan. Su gran sueño es poder poner una panadería para ir construyendo un patrimonio para sus hijos. 

“En un año vendiendo pan nos han pasado varias cosas, nos caímos en un charco de lodo, nos corretean los perros y nos hemos quedado sin gasolina, ya es parte de nuestra experiencia”

El grupo agradece los préstamos otorgados y continuarán invitando a más personas para que también puedan impulsar sus actividades.

*El campo de la comunidad fue el lugar que eligieron las clientas para tomarse la fotografía, doña Modesta viste blusa color rojo.
texts.en:
The quiet, climate and view that the community where the group "El Esfuerzo 2" are very relaxing. A month ago the sugar cane harvesting period began and with it the reactivation of the region's economy as the majority of the inhabitants of the community work in the fields. While others like the members of this group have their businesses:

Viviana - groceries
Adela - Tamales
Modesta - bread
Laura - mojarra (fish)
Cruz - cosmetics
Marcela – catalog footwear
Felicita – Nixtamal (corn) mill
Maura - groceries
Rosalia - corn flour
Reyna - snacks
Ángel, Ignacio - Mojarra (fish)
Reyna - groceries
Adriana - chicken
Clara – tortillas

Buying and reselling bread is the business that Modesta has been doing for 1 year. Mounted on her motorcycle from 4 in the morning she is off to buy bread and then travels through the streets selling it. When she started the business her investment was very small but in a few months she got her first loan from VisionFund which increased the amount of pieces she could buy.

Today Modesta is looking for a provider so she can get more accessible prices. Modesta is the mother of 3 children, one of whom helps her drive the motorcycles for the afternoon sales. Felix, Modesta's husband works in the fields and the continuity of his work is important for paying the household expenses.

This loan Modesta needs to buy a new basket and more bread. Her great dream is to open a bakery to build a legacy for her children. "In a year of selling bread a lot of things have happened. We fell into a mud puddle, the dogs have chased us and we have been stranded without gasoline. All this is our experience".

The group is grateful for the loans given and continue to invite more people so that they can boost their businesses. The community's common was the place where the group decided to take the photo. Modesta is wearing the red colored blouse.

loans.use: to buy a basket and bread.

location.town: Cañada san Antonio,  Acatlan de Perez Figueroa, Oa

loans.name: Hernan

texts.en: Originally from Ecuador, and after a few years working as a bus driver, Hernan has the opportunity to buy his own truck and start his business as an Independent contractor. The $1350 loan will help to make the down payment for a truck. This new venture will allow him to earn more money and to provide all the things that he needs for his family.

loans.use: To pay the down payment to purchase a truck

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es: Rolando works as a waiter at his parents restaurant he is doing that since 4 years ago he is single and he doesnt have children but Rolando has an ambition to have his own business in that way he needs a loan to put a tucumana stand (a tucumana is a junk food like a burrito the tucumana is delicious and very demanded in Bolivia) he wants to sell his tucumanas in the mornings he wont be cooking the food but he will attend the stand in the picture Rolando appears at his parents restaurant after hi finished his work day
texts.en:
Rolando has been working as a waiter at his parents restaurant for four years. He is single and has no have children. 

But Rolando has ambition to own a business in that way he needs a loan in order to set up his food selling business.  He says burritos are in high demand in Bolivia.

In the photo, Rolando appears at his parents restaurant after finishing a day's work.

loans.use: to set up his food selling business.

loans.name: Nada

texts.en:
Nada is a 42 year-old Lebanese married woman living with four children. Her husband is a really hard worker who expends great effort to support his family. 

Two years ago, Nada started making and selling tasty homemade food. 

Nada is asking for a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase raw materials and other supplies to increase her productivity. Nada is certain that the loan will have a positive effect on her income.

loans.use: to purchase cooking supplies.

loans.name: Layale

texts.en:
Layale is a 33 year-old Lebanese married woman living with four kids. She owns and operates a homemade food business from her kitchen at home. 

She is a hardworking woman and acts as the sole breadwinner for her modest family. 

Through the loan she will obtain from Kiva partner Vitas. s.a.l., she is planning to purchase raw material and other items such as cooking equipment to grow her business and increase her production capacity.

loans.use: to purchase raw material and cooking equipment.

loans.name: Tulaga Muruaki Self Help Group

texts.en:
Bilhah, in the middle in the photograph, is a member of Tulaga Muruaki Self Help Group. She is twenty-six years old and a mother of three children who attend school. Bilhah is a vegetable farmer and also operates a tailoring business. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to learn more about enterprise development, record keeping, and financial management.
She is borrowing a loan to help boost her farming business by buying certified seeds to improve on crop yield. She will also expand her tailoring business by buying more stock of sewing threads and textile fabrics. This will ensure that she can meet customers' rising demands and thus be in a position to increase her income. She plans to use the anticipated income to meet her family's needs, such as those in food and clothing.
She is grateful to Kiva for their help and support.

loans.use: To buy more textile fabrics and sewing threads for her tailoring business and to buy certified seeds that will help improve crop yield.

loans.name: Erick

texts.en: Erick left Guatemala 12 years ago with a bag full of hope. During his life in Guatemala, he trained as an electrician apprentice since he was 13 years of age. He also received technical training as an electrician that he planned to use in the United States to open a small business.  When he arrived on the east coast, he humbly began working in construction but never lost his idea of being his own boss. After many sacrifices, he finally decided to open his own electrician business this year (2014) under his own name. The $9875 loan that was provided to him, is going to be used to buy the necessary tools and equipment so he can start operations.

loans.use: To purchase tools

loans.name: Bukhari Mahila Mandal-001 Group

texts.en:
Nazmaben, the group leader (lady in the center), hails from the Surendranagar district in Gujarat. She lives in a large family of 7 people with her husband and a young child. To supplement her family income, she runs her own small beauty parlor business. Her income of 5,000 India Rupees (INR) helps her to supplement her family income and she saves the entire amount. But these savings are meager and will not help her realize her biggest hope. She wants to provide a good education and better healthcare for her child. She has done her primary schooling and had to drop out to financial constraints, so she understands the importance of education. Increasing her income will also help improve her family’s standard of living. 

She wants to expand her microenterprise by offering more services in her beauty parlor like hair cutting, facials, and waxing. This will bring more customers and, therefore, increase her income. She stands to net an increase income of 9000 rupees each month. Of this, she will save 4000 rupees for her child’s education and her other goals, and will reinvest the rest in making her business self-sustainable. Local banks will not provide the microfinance Nazmaben needs to expand her small business. 

She has joined with four other local women who run similar small businesses and want to expand their enterprises. Batulben, Vimalaben, Nitaben, and Svatiben also want to expand their respective tailoring, sopari (mouth-fresheners), and bandhani work (tie-dying) businesses.

Your loan will help these women to expand their small businesses, increase their incomes, and provide a better quality of life and education for their children. This will provide them and their families financial security and stability.

loans.use: To expand her beauty parlor business by providing more services like haircuts, facials, and waxing.

loans.name: Poonam Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Parulben leads a group of five women micro entrepreneurs from Chandkheda, a part of Ahmedabad, the largest city in Gujarat. Featured in the center of the picture, 40-year-old Parulben runs her own small business. She purchases decorative articles in bulk from the wholesale markets and sells them locally for a profit. After expenses for purchases and transportation, she takes home an income of 3000 India Rupees (INR) per month. This meager sum contributes 25% of her family’s income. Married, Parulben lives with her husband and two more family members. Their monthly savings of 5000 rupees provides a financial cushion during emergencies. But to ensure a better living standard, cope with rising costs, and build a stable nest-egg for the old age, they need to start earning and saving more. 

Seeking to improve her own situation, Parulben has decided to crowdfund an enterprise loan together with her hardworking and determined group members. They seek a loan of 65,000 rupees. Parulben will use her share of the loan to invest in buying sari laces, colorful artificial flowers, and stoles, which fetch a higher demand and profits. This investment will result in increased sales and margins, leading to an increase of 5000 rupees in her enterprise income. She will set some of this aside as savings and reinvest the rest into her business. Parulben’s plans are long-term. She wants to convert her business into a sustainable income source. Her group members Kokilaben, Vasantiben, Madhuba, and Bhavnaben will similarly use the loan to expand their decorative materials businesses. They need the extra income to ensure a healthy and bright future for their children. 

Parulben and her group are ready to apply all their energy for the well-being of their families. Your loan will help them achieve their goals.

loans.use: To purchase stoles, artificial flowers, and laces for saris as inventory for growing her decorative articles microenterprise.

loans.name: Keshar Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
30-year-old Kamuben (pictured at center) hails from Chandkheda in Ahmedabad district, Gujarat. This determined lady runs a small scale business and sells decorative items, such as lace used in saris, artificial flowers, and stoles. The income of 3000 India Rupees (INR) she earns through this business accounts for almost 30% of her household income. Together with her husband, she saves 3500 rupees per month. They have a young child of pre-school age, and are saving for their child’s future education. A young couple, their current savings will not be adequate to cover education costs as well as provide a buffer during emergencies. 

Seeking to improve her family’s standard of living and guarantee enough savings for her child’s future, Kamuben has decided to grow her decorative items business. She wants to stock up the fast-selling and profit fetching items on her inventory in bulk and greater variety. This will help her cater to the demand for these items in a semi-urban thriving area like Chandkheda, especially during the auspicious wedding and festive season. This initiative will increase her income by 2000 rupees, which is a significant figure for her, amounting to a 66% hike, given her current modest earnings. The rest of her profits, she will invest in the further development of her business. 

Kamuben's other team members, Ushaben, Geetaben, and Kokilaben also want to develop their own decorative items businesses to an appreciable position. Another team mate, Sarojben, wants to expand her sari selling small business. These hard working and confident women lack the funds for initial capital. So they seek a loan of 50,000 rupees, which they will repay within 12 months in installments. 

Your loan will help five families access an enhanced income that will help them to secure their childrens' futures. Having had a very basic primary education due to her family’s socio-economic limitations, Kamuben is very determined to put her child through college. She is particularly thankful for your support and this opportunity.

loans.use: To buy more decorative sari lace, artificial flowers, and stoles and grow her decorative articles business.

loans.name: Theodomile

texts.en:
Theodomile is 30 years old. He is not married. He has a shop and has been working in a business for six years.

With the loan, he would like to buy books, cooking oil, and soap to resell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest.

loans.use: to buy books, cooking oil, and soap to resell.

loans.name: Nelvie

texts.en:
Nelvie is 25 years old and married. She lives in Mahayag, Molave, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. For the past two years, Nelvie has been a farmer. She earns 1,500 PHP each month.

She is a new member of PMPC. Nelvie is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to purchase fertilizer, to make the growth of rice healthy. In the future, she hopes to become engaged in another business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Claudia Guadalupe

texts.es: Claudia es una mujer de 28 años de edad que habita en vivienda propia desde hace 28 años ya que su vivienda proviene de una herencia familiar. Ella es una mujer emprendedora que se gana la vida con su negocio de fabricación y comercialización de telas, actividad que realiza desde hace 7 años, por lo que gracias a su experiencia y buenos tratos cuenta con una gran cantidad de clientes que solicitan sus productos. Claudia desea construir una galera la cual le permita proteger de la lluvia y el sol los telares que son su única fuente de ingresos, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: vara de castilla, madera, clavos y lámina galvanizada para construir una galera en su vivienda lo antes posible.
texts.en: Claudia, 28, lives in the house where she was born and raised.  She inherited it from her family and operates her textile-manufacturing business there.  She started making textiles when she was 7 years old and has many regular customers who value what she makes.  Claudia is applying to FUSAI for a loan that she will use to buy materials--beams, nails, roofing--for a porch that she wants to build.  The porch will protect her textiles--her only source of income--from the sun and rain.

loans.use: to pay for improvements to her house.

loans.name: Betsy Alicia

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Florón de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Grupo de Crédito Renacer.
En este lugar vive la señora Betsy, tiene 41 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y de esta relación tiene 5  hijos, tres mayores de edad y dos de 13 y 9 años que estudian en colegio y escuela y son los que aun viven en su casa. Su esposo es albañil.
Doña Betsy para ayudarle a su marido en los gastos que genera el hogar hace varios años construyo una pequeña graja en la cual  se dedica a la cría de pollos, ella compra los pollos pequeños para luego alimentarlos y cuidarlos por tres meses tiempo necesario para que estén listos para la venta, los vende a vecinos del lugar o entregarlos a los comerciantes que llegan hasta su casa a comprar sus animales. Así ella se gana algo que le sirve para salir adelante.
Este crédito es para comprar alimentos y medicinas para los pollos. Lleva 2 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por los servicios adicionales que ofrece la institución como el seguro médico gratuito. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The citadel of El Florón is in the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, known for many years as the city of the Reales Tamarindos. The members of the Renacer group meet every fifteen days in El Floron.
Betsy lives in El Floron. She is 41 and is in a common law relationship. She has five children, three of whom are grown. The others, ages 9 and 13, study and are the only ones who still live with her. Her husband is a bricklayer.
In order to help her husband with the general household costs, Betsy built a small coop a few years ago where she raises chickens. She buys little chickens to feed and raise for three months until they are ready for sale. She sells to her neighbours or to merchants to come to her home to buy the animals. This is how she makes something to help her get ahead.
This loan is for the purchase of food and medicine for the chickens. She has been in the group for two years and likes it because of the additional services that the institution offers, such as free medical insurance. Her dreams are to give her children the best.

loans.use: to buy chicken feed and medicine.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia lives in Ermera. She is married and her husband is working in the hospital. She has been involved in business activities since 2009. She started with her own working capital of $600. She is a businesswoman. So she is requesting a loan of $800 from Tuba Rai Metin because she wants to improve her business. She is very interested in her business, so she is taking this loan from Tuba Rai Metin to buy more goods such as sugar, aqua, cigarettes, biscuits, sweets, milk, detergent, shampoo, eggs, candles and other things to sell including soft drinks. She needs the loan from Tuba Rai Metin because she wants to improve the management of her business and she hopes to open a bigger store in the future. Emilia also has animals like pigs, chickens and dogs.

loans.use: To buy sugar, aqua, cigarettes, biscuits, sweets, milk, detergent, shampoo, eggs, candles and other things to sell including soft drinks.

loans.name: Lynnie

texts.en:
Lynnie works hard to support her family. Lynnie is married and has a fish pond business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of feed.

Lynnie has been in this business for five years now.

In the future, Lynnie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of feed

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en:
Abubakar is a maize farmer from Hayin Malam Bawa village in Kaduna state.

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Abubakar would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Abubakar can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

Abubakar, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Amadu

texts.en: Amadu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Amadu joined Babban Gona, primarily to create a better future for his children, Abdullashi and Ahamsi.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Amadu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Amadu can now store his maize at harvest time. He can sell it a few months later, at a price up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Amadu spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children. He hopes eventually to ensure that his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for child school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ashiru

texts.en: Ashiru is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Ashiru joined Babban Gona, primarily to create a better future for his children, Mubarak, Muhammadu and Abubakar.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ashiru would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ashiru can now store his maize at harvest time. He can sell it a few months later, at a price up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Ashiru spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children. He hopes eventually to make more money, for himself and his family.

loans.use: to pay for child school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nada

texts.en:
Nada is a 28 year-old married Lebanese mother of two children. Her husband is a hard worker. 

Three years ago she started an agriculture business to boost her family's income. 

Today, she is asking for a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase agriculture supplies.  

Nada says she is very excited to receive the loan and has no doubt that it will bring positive results.

loans.use: to purchase agriculture supplies.

loans.name: Gratien

texts.en:
Gratien is 33 years old. He is married with two children ages two and five. His oldest child attends school.

He has farmed for 11 years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizer to grow maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his employees.
-----------------------
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to grow maize.

loans.name: Manale

texts.en:
Manale is a 22 year-old married Lebanese woman and mother of two children. Her husband is a vegetable seller. 

Manale is a hard-working woman and a great mother who is making a strong effort to meet the needs of her family. Two years ago, she started producing homemade food from her home in order to provide extra financial support. 

Through this youth loan she will obtain from Kiva partner Vitas. s.a.l., she is planning to purchase necessities such as bottles, pots and jars that can improve her business and increase its productivity. 

Manale is certain that the loan will have a positive effect on her income.

loans.use: to purchase items like bottles, pots and jars.

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.en:
Pascaline is 44 years old. She is married with 8 children aged between 6 and 24 years old, all of whom go to school. She has been farming for 21 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for her workers.


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize.

loans.name: Antoine

texts.en:
Antoine is a 42-year-old married man without children. He has farmed for 19 years. He will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize.  The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 32 years old. He is married with four children aged between 2 and 10 years, three of whom go to school. He has farmed for 13 years. He will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his employees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow maize and sell the maize.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for improvements to her house.

loans.name: Ma. Cynthia

texts.en:
Ma. Cynthia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish pond operator business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy additional feed for her fish pond business.

Ma. Cynthia has been in this business for two years. Ma. Cynthia earns more income from raising pigs.

Ma. Cynthia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional feed for her fish pond

loans.name: Balarabe

texts.en: Balarabe is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Balarabe would have had to sell his  maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Balarabe can now store his maize at harvest time. He can sell it a few months later, at a price up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked about his goals, Balarabe expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Cholpon

texts.ru: Чолпон, 51 год, есть сын, замужем. Образование у Чолпон среднее, в качестве дополнительного дохода для своей семьи, занимается животноводством, стартовав 14 лет назад с 5,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Чолпон, на данный момент в ее хозяйстве имеется 2 коровы и 10 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет примерно 15,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Чолпон обратилась в Банк «Бай–Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 45,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец. Доходы от кредита Чолпон планирует вложить в дальнейшее расширение бизнеса.
texts.en:
Cholpon is 51 years old, has a son and is married. She has secondary education. She is engaged in livestock breeding as an additional income for her family, after having started 14 years ago with 5,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Cholpon's persistent work, she currently has two cows and ten sheep. The monthly income is approximately 15,000 som (KGS).

With an aim to further develop her business, Cholpon turned to the bank "Bai Tushum" for a loan in the amount of 45,000 som (KGS) to purchase sheep. Cholpon plans to invest the income from the loan in further expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sheep in order to increase her headcount of livestock

loans.name: Octaviana

texts.en:
A USD 800 loan is offered to Octavia to improve her business. Octavia opened her kiosk in 2013 with her own working capital. 

She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store, like oils, fish, noodles, cigarettes, sugar, salt, milk, bread, and candles. She is generating a good income from selling.

Octavia has been thinking of running a big business after years of involving herself in doing business. She is living in a town with her family. Her husband is a farmer and she is happy with this loan because it will improve her living conditions in the future.

loans.use: to buy oils, fish, noodles, cigarettes, sugar, salt, milk, bread, and candles.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn works hard to support her family. Marilyn is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase an additional bundle of fishing net.

Marilyn has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Marilyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase an additional bundle of fishing net

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to wire her house for electricity.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: El joven a quien se le ha pixeleado la cara por tener 22 años de edad y vivir en zona de alto riego, se dedica desde hace algunos años al cultivo de arroz, el joven vive en casa propia con su compañera de vida, no tienen hijos todavía, el esta solicitando nuevamente un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, herbicidas, etc. y mejorar el terreno que muestra en la fotografía ya que le ha ido muy bien en sus cultivos en estos últimos meses y asi poder seguir teniendo mejores ganancias.
texts.en: This young man, whose face is obscured, is 22 years old and lives in a high risk neighborhood.  For a number of years he has been cultivating rice.  He lives in his own home with his life partner; they do not yet have any children.  He is requesting another loan to buy chemical and organic fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides, etc., to improve his land, which is seen in the photograph, because his crops have been doing very well in the latest months, and so he wants to continue to obtain more earnings.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add a bathroom and septic tank.

loans.name: Muhayyo

texts.ru:
Мухайё верная жена и мать четверых детей. Ей 35 лет. Ее муж находиться за рубежом. Он не смог найти работу на районе, и был вынужден уехать, чтобы прокормить семью. Мухайё с четырьмя малолетними детьми живет на районе Шахритус. Воспитанием детей занимается одна Мухайё.
   Мухайё домохозяйка, но она сидя дома, занимается животноводством. В свободное от домашних дел время Мухайё работает на скотном дворе. У нее не много скотов, потому что раньше она много времени уделяла детям, теперь все ее дети учатся в школе и у Мухайё остается много времени. Она не собирается это время тратить впустую. Мухайё решила обратиться за кредитом и увеличить поголовья скота и увеличить доход от животноводческой деятельности.
texts.en:
Muhayyo is a faithful wife and the mother of four children. She is 35 years old. Her husband is abroad. He was not able to find work in their region, and had to travel in order to feed his family. Muhayyo and her four small children live in the Shahritus region. 

Muhayyo raises her children alone. She is a housewife, but she works with livestock breeding at home. In the time free from household work, Muhayyo works in the livestock yard. She does not have a lot of livestock, because earlier she spent a lot of time on her children. 

Currently all the children go to school, and Muhayyo has a lot of time. She decided to not waste this time. Muhayyo decided to apply for a loan and increase the number of livestock and her income from the livestock breeding business.

loans.use: to increase the number of livestock

loans.name: Dolores Veronica

texts.es: Dolores es una mujer de 39 años de edad que se gana la vida con la venta de diferentes artículos del hogar como: toallas, manteles, sabanas, ropa interior, etc. Dicha actividad la realiza desde hace 7 años, por lo que se siente feliz de poder sostener la economía de su hogar gracias a su negocio. Ella habita en vivienda propia al lado de su compañero de vida y sus 2 hijos de 17 y 6 años de edad. Dolores desea invertir en su negocio ya que sabe que es la única fuente de ingreso con la que cuanta y desea aprovechar la época navideña para mejorar sus ganancias, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: toallas, manteles, mantas, ropa interior, sandalias, etc.
texts.en:
Dolores is a 39-year-old woman who makes a living selling different household items such as: towels, tablecloths, sheets, undergarments, etc. She has been doing this work for seven years, for which she is happy to be able to support the household expenses, thanks to her business. 

She lives in her own home beside her life partner and children, ages six and seventeen. Dolores hopes to invest in her business since she knows it is the only source of income to rely on and she hopes to make the most of the Christmas season to improve her profits. 

She is requesting a loan from FUSAI to buy: towels, tablecloths, blankets, undergarments, sandals, etc.

loans.use: to buy: towels, tablecloths, blankets, undergarments, sandals, etc

loans.name: Augustin

texts.en:
Augustin is 36 years old and is married.

He is a farmer and has been farming for 8 years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers to grow maize and then sell the maize.

The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow and sell maize.

loans.name: Mkananda Group

texts.en:
Zainabu, who is in her mid 20s, is married with two children, one is still small and the other one is in school. She has been running two projects, Selling small, dry, fish called dagga and fabrics. She works from 10am to 5pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Zainabu's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to start selling fabrics and to increase her dagga stock. She paid back her loan successfully. She used the profit to keep some in her bank account and covered household expenses. She will use this loan to increase her stock of small, dry, fish and to buy fabrics to resell. She dreams of owning a big fabric shop.

Zainabu will share this loan with her loan group Mkananda which has four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase her stock of small, dry, fish (dagga) and to buy fabrics to resell.

loans.name: Fe Y Esperanza Group

texts.es:
LA ASOCIACIÓN COMUNAL FE Y ESPERANZA ESTA CONFORMADA POR OCHO INTEGRANTES MADRES SOLTERAS  RESPONSABLES DE QUINCE HIJOS BAJO SU RESPONSABILIDAD, SON ORIGINARIAS DE MALPAISILLO, SE CARACTERIZAN POR SER TRABAJADORAS , RESPONSABLES, CON GANAS DE SUPERACIÓN PERSONAL, TODAS TIENEN DIFERENTES TIPO DE NEGOCIO QUE ES EL SOSTÉN DE SU FAMILIA , EL CUAL LES AYUDA A SALIR ADELANTE CON SUS HIJOS Y BRINDARLES OPORTUNIDADES MEJORES DE VIDA,  YA QUE ELLOS LAMENTABLEMENTE NO PUDIERON ESTUDIAR POR FALTA DE RECURSOS ECONÓMICOS.
EN LA ACTUALIZAD LA COORDINADORA ES  MARÍA DEL SOCORRO  Y TIENE POR ACTIVIDAD ECONÓMICA LA VENTA DE COSMÉTICOS DE FORMA AMBULANTE Y EN SU CASA DE HABITACIÓN,  ELLA DEDICA A SU NEGOCIO UNA OCHO HORAS DIARIAS OFRECIENDO SUS PRODUCTOS, TODOS LOS DÍAS RECORRE LAS CALLES EN BUSCA DE CLIENTE FIJOS Y EVENTUALES ENTREGANDO SU MERCADERÍA Y  RECUPERA LAS GANANCIAS DE FORMA SEMANAL Y QUINCENAL SEGÚN LA FRECUENCIA DE PAGO DE SUS CLIENTES EL NEGOCIO CONSISTE EN VENDER COSMÉTICOS COMO:  LABIALES, DELINEADORES, MARBELLINE, SOMBRA DE OJOS, LÁPIZ DE OJOS, RUBOR, PERFUMES, BODY DE CUERPOS, VANIDADES, ETC.  EL OBJETIVO EN INVERTIR EN CAPITAL DE TRABAJO Y SURTIR SU NEGOCIO PARA QUE EN UN FUTURO NO MUY LEJANO PUEDA OBTENER MEJORES INGRESOS. FE Y ESPERANZA AGRADECE LA AYUDA QUE LOS INVERSIONISTAS KIVA LE BRINDAN A PERSONAS DE ESCASOS RECURSOS Y PAÍSES POBRE COMO ES  NICARAGUA PARA TENER UN MEDIO DE TRABAJO DIGNO.
texts.en:
The Fe y Esperanza community group has eight members, all single mothers, who are responsible for a total of fifteen children. They are from Malpaisillo and are hard-working, responsible, and have a desire to get ahead. They all have different kinds of businesses to sustain their families and get ahead, offering their children opportunities for better lives. Unfortunately these women were not able to study due to lack of economic resources.
The current coordinator is Maria del Socorro. She sells cosmetics on the street and from her home. She spends 8 hours per day on her business. Every day she walks the streets looking for her fixed clients as well as other clients. She delivers her merchandise and charges weekly and biweekly depending on her customers. She sells cosmetics such as lip products, liners, Marbelline, eyeshadow, eyeliner, blush, and perfume. 
Her goal in investing this capital is to stock her business so that in the near future she will have a greater income.
The Fe y Esperanza group is grateful for the support that Kiva lenders offer to persons with low recourses in poorer countries such as Nicaragua so that they can work.

loans.use: to invest in cosmetics such as lip products, liners, marbelline, eyeshadow, eyeliner, blush, perfumes, etc.

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean Damascene is 25 years old and married with one, one year old child. 

He has farmed for six years and will use the loan from Kiva, to buy fertilizers to grow and sell maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his employees.
---------------------------------
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow and sell maize.

loans.name: Muzamiru

texts.en:
Muzamiru is a 38-year-old married man with three kids who are 6, 4 and 3 months old. He lives in a rural area with his family and he deals in agriculture, specifically growing coffee. He supplements his income with income from a retail shop. 

He works eight hours a day, six days a week. He has been in this business since 2012, and he started it with the aim of increasing his family's income. He has acquired this loan in order to buy fertilizers. His customers are traders from cities.

His dream is to build rentals in the nearby trading centre. His challenges are lack of enough capital, and pests and disease which attack crops. He describes himself as an honest man and asks the lenders to reduce the interest.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers

loans.name: Valens

texts.en:
